description: Comprehensive mapping of visual assets to mastery goals and misconceptions for formative assessment

images.imagePrompt: Create an SVG illustration showing two cookie pieces side-by-side on a plain white background. The left cookie piece should be approximately 3 times larger than the right cookie piece, making the size difference VERY obvious and unmistakable. Both pieces should have a warm brown color (#D2691E) with chocolate chip spots (small dark brown circles). The large piece should measure roughly 180px wide Ã— 120px tall, while the small piece should be 60px wide Ã— 40px tall. Use rounded, organic shapes to look like broken cookie pieces. Add a subtle shadow beneath each piece. The visual contrast should be so clear that even a young child can immediately see one is 'big' and one is 'tiny'. Include simple texture details: 3-4 chocolate chips on the large piece, 1-2 on the small piece.
masteryGoalDescriptions: Recognize that fractions require equal parts - this image assesses whether student can identify unequal parts

misconceptionsToDetect.description: Thinking any division creates fractions, even if parts are unequal
detectionCriteria: Student says 'these are halves' when pieces are clearly unequal
Student doesn't notice size difference
Student focuses on count (2 pieces) not size

images.assessmentQuestion: Look at these two cookie pieces. Are they the same size? Could we call them halves?

correctResponse.reasoning: Student recognizes size difference and understands equal parts requirement

incorrectResponse.reasoning: Student may have unequal-parts misconception or not yet understand equal partitioning requirement

scaffolding.low: Look closely - is this cookie piece bigger than this one? Put your hands apart to show me the size of each piece.
scaffolding.medium: If we gave these two pieces to two friends, would that be fair? Why or why not?
scaffolding.high: Could we call these 'halves'? What would need to be true for them to be halves?

agentDrawingPrompts.initial: I'm showing you two cookie pieces on your screen. Can you circle the bigger piece on your canvas? Then tell me what you notice about their sizes.
agentDrawingPrompts.encouragement: Try using your drawing tools! Circle or mark each cookie piece so we can compare them.
agentDrawingPrompts.guidance: That's a start! Now can you show me which one is bigger? Maybe draw an arrow or write 'BIG' and 'SMALL' next to them.
agentDrawingPrompts.completion: Great! Now tell me - are these pieces the same size? Could we call them halves?

expectedElements: Marks or circles identifying the two cookie pieces
Labels or arrows showing size difference
Visual comparison indicators (arrows, lines, words)
commonErrors: No marking or annotation on canvas
Marking both as equal when they're clearly different
Only identifying one piece instead of comparing both
successIndicators: Uses visual markers to show difference

images.whenToPromptDrawing: Immediately after showing the image, before asking the assessment question

images.imagePrompt: Create an SVG illustration showing three diverse children standing side-by-side, each holding a cookie piece of different sizes. Left: Carlos (Latino, short brown hair, green t-shirt) holding a TINY cookie piece (50px wide) with a sad expression (downturned mouth, slightly furrowed brows, perhaps a small tear). Center: Maya (African American, hair in two puffs, yellow t-shirt) holding a MEDIUM cookie piece (90px wide) with a neutral expression (straight mouth, regular eyes). Right: Luna (Asian, long black hair, purple t-shirt) holding a LARGE cookie piece (140px wide) with a guilty/uncomfortable expression (biting lip, eyes looking down/away, slight frown). Place simple cookie pieces in front of each child at chest height. Use warm, friendly art style appropriate for grade 3. Background should be minimal - perhaps a simple party table or plain with subtle confetti dots. Each child should be approximately 250px tall. The emotional expressions should be clear and age-appropriate, conveying the unfairness of the situation. Add small details like party hats to suggest birthday context.
masteryGoalDescriptions: Recognize that fractions require equal parts - assessed through fairness context which connects to equal sharing

misconceptionsToDetect.description: Not recognizing that fairness requires equal-sized parts
detectionCriteria: Student says situation is fair when pieces are unequal
Student says 'everyone got a piece' without noticing sizes
Student doesn't connect fairness to equal size

images.assessmentQuestion: Look at what each friend got. Is this fair? Why do you think Carlos looks sad and Luna looks guilty?

correctResponse.reasoning: Student connects emotions to unequal distribution and understands fairness requires equal parts

incorrectResponse.reasoning: Student may not yet understand that fairness requires equal-sized parts, not just equal count

scaffolding.low: Point to the cookie pieces. Which one is biggest? Which is smallest? How do you think Carlos feels?
scaffolding.medium: If you were Carlos, how would you feel? What would make it fair?
scaffolding.high: What's the rule for fair sharing? How could Luna fix this problem?

Circle C: Divided into 2 EQUAL parts (perfect halves) with one vertical line through the center, creating two 180Â° semicircles.

Recognize equal vs unequal partitioning requirement

misconceptionsToDetect.description: Accepting unequal parts as valid fractions
detectionCriteria: Student says Circle B shows equal parts
Student says all three are equal
Student focuses on number of parts (3) not size

images.assessmentQuestion: Which circles show EQUAL parts? How can you tell?

incorrectResponse.reasoning: Student may have unequal-parts misconception or needs to develop visual discrimination

agentDrawingPrompts.initial: Here's a blank circle on your canvas! Your job is to divide it into equal parts. Let's start with halves - can you draw a line to split this circle into 2 equal pieces?

incorrectResponse.reasoning: Student lacks clear strategy for ensuring equal partitioning

expectedElements: Vertical lines dividing the rectangle

commonErrors: Too few or too many lines for intended partitioning
successIndicators: Student can count and verify equal parts

images.whenToPromptDrawing: Immediately after showing the blank rectangle template

usageGuidelines.assessmentFlow: Start with prerequisite images (order 1-2) if gaps detected. Progress through formative practice images (order 4-8), use checkpoint (order 9) to verify mastery, advance to notation and critical thinking (order 10-11), offer extension challenges (order 13-14) for advanced learners, conclude with reflection (order 15).

adaptivePathways.strugglingLearner: Use scaffolding images (order 12), provide more time with models (order 5, 7, 8), offer additional prerequisite practice (order 1-2).
adaptivePathways.onTrackLearner: Follow standard progression (order 1-11), include checkpoint (order 9), complete with reflection (order 15).
adaptivePathways.advancedLearner: Accelerate through prerequisites, focus on critical thinking (order 11), provide extension challenges (order 13-14), emphasize transfer and generalization.

usageGuidelines.misconceptionDetection: Each image with misconceptions listed should be analyzed using VisionService + student verbal explanation. Look for evidence keywords in transcription. Confidence threshold indicates minimum confidence for flagging.
usageGuidelines.formativeAssessment: Every image is an assessment opportunity. Compare student's canvas drawing to expected response indicators. Use incorrect response indicators to detect misconceptions early.
